{{Infobox website | name = {{Wiki favicon}} Bengali Wikipedia | screenshot = বাংলা উইকিপিডিয়ার প্রধান পাতা.png | screenshot_size = 250px | logo = Wikipedia-logo-v2-bn.svg | logo_size = 85% | collapsible = yes | caption = The homepage of the Bengali Wikipedia. | url = [http://bn.wikipedia.org/ bn.wikipedia.org] | commercial = No | location = [[Dhaka]] & [[Kolkata]] | type = [[Internet encyclopedia project]] | language = [[Bengali language|Bengali]] | registration = Optional | owner = [[Wikimedia Foundation]] | num_users = {{NUMBEROF|USERS|bn|N}} | launch_date = {{Start date and age|2004|01|27|df=no}} | author = | current_status = online }}
The '''Bengali Wikipedia''' or '''Bangla Wikipedia''' ({{lang-bn|{{#property:P1448}}}}, ''Bānglā u'ikipiḍiẏā'') is the [[Bengali language]] edition of [[Wikipedia]], the free online encyclopedia. It also has a phonetic Latin alphabet to [[Bengali script]] tool so Latin alphabet keyboards can be used to type Bengali without downloading any software.
Launched in January 27, 2004, it surpassed 10,000 articles in October 2006, becoming the second South-Asian language to do so.<ref name="Nazmul">{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/tech/news/article_1206718.php/Bengali_Wikipedia_crosses_10000_articles|title=Bengali Wikipedia crosses 10,000 articles|last=Noronha|first=Frederick|date=September 30, 2006|work=[[Indo-Asian News Service]]|publisher=[[Monsters and Critics]]|access-date=25 December 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131226084330/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/tech/news/article_1206718.php/Bengali_Wikipedia_crosses_10000_articles|archivedate=26 December 2013|df=}}</ref> In {{Date}}, total article crossed [[Special:Statistics|{{NUMBEROF|ARTICLES|bn|N}}]] articles.<ref>This prediction is based on <nowiki>{{NUMBEROF|ARTICLES|bn|N}}</nowiki> Wikipedia template that automatically updates article numbers. So this is not a permanent or fixed count. The number of articles shown here, change in real-time as soon as a new article is created or removed. Therefore, this is not a reliable source and the numbers shown here are subject to change without prior notice.</ref><ref name=DS-1>{{cite news|title=A decade of Bangla Wikipedia An open call|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/bytes/a-decade-of-bangla-wikipedia-an-open-call-15875|access-date=15 April 2014|newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)]]|date=March 17, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140323090248/http://www.thedailystar.net/bytes/a-decade-of-bangla-wikipedia-an-open-call-15875|archivedate=23 March 2014|df=}}</ref> Community-produced news publications include ‘[[WikiBarta]]’.
==Early History== In February 2002, the developers started creating language-code based sub-domains for different language Wikipedias. Along with other Wikipedia sub-domains, Bengali language sub-domain was created at that time. A placeholder page was created automatically in that sub-domain on June 1, 2002. On December 9, 2003, A Bangladeshi Ph.D. student of Canada's McGill University named Shah Asaduzzaman emailed Wikipedia Founder [[Jimmy Wales]] with a request to create Bengali Wikipedia. As a result, the developers created a test page on the Wikipedia named "Home Page" on December 26 of the same year.
The Main Page of Bengali Wikipedia was created on January 27, 2004 from an IP address which marks the official beginning of Bengali Wikipedia. '[[:bn:বাংলা ভাষা|বাংলা ভাষা]]' ("Bānglā Bhāshā"; Bengali Language in English) is the first article of Bengali Wikipedia which was created on May 24, 2004.
==History== Bengali Wikipedia started its journey in January 27, 2004.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.kalerkantho.com/online/techbishwa/2017/02/25/467581|title=একনজরে বাংলা উইকিপিডিয়া - কালের কণ্ঠ|first=Kaler|last=Kantho|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kalerkantho.com/print-edition/tech-everyday/2018/01/28/595065|title=১৪ বছরে বাংলা উইকিপিডিয়া - কালের কণ্ঠ|first=Kaler|last=Kantho|publisher=}}</ref> Back then, the people of [[Bangladesh]] had a little interest in Wikipedia. A few students and scholars used the [[English Wikipedia]], but it was not accountable. Besides that, there were various difficulties contributing in Bengali. The whole scenario has been changed in 2006.<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=http://www.kalerkantho.com/online/techbishwa/2017/02/25/467571|title=যুগ পেরিয়ে বাংলা উইকিপিডিয়া - কালের কণ্ঠ|first=Kaler|last=Kantho|publisher=}}</ref> During that time, the Bengali blogging world was growing slowly, and many people became accustomed to Bengali computing where a [[free and open-source]] Bengali typing tool, [[Avro Keyboard]] played a key role. On March 25, 2006, a Wiki team was created by the ‘Bangladesh Open Source Network’ (BdOSN) to popularize Wikipedia throughout the country.<ref name="auto1"/> The aim was to represent the country to the world through Wikipedia and build a complete encyclopedia in Bengali.
At that time, Bengali Wikipedia had only 500 articles. ‘BdOSN wiki team’ managed to spread the word through some newspapers and start a Bengali Wiki mailing list. Soon, many Bengali-speaking people from Bangladesh and abroad joined them in this dynamic project. As a result, by the end of the October, Bengali Wikipedia got to 10,000 articles.<ref name="auto1"/> Among the South Asian language Wikipedias, Bengali Wikipedia reached that milestone first, and many of these articles were illustrated with photos from the demonstrator of [[Bengali language movement|Bengali Language Movement]] Dr. Rafiqul Islam, who donated all his historical photographs taken during the language movement to [[Wikimedia Commons]].<ref name="auto1"/>
One of the pioneer of the Bengali Wikipedia, Dr. Ragib Hasan said that {{quote|“The biggest challenge was writing something on internet in Bengali. The Bengali Unicode was not supported on most operating systems, only few websites on the internet supported Bengali Unicode, and users had difficulties configuring it. Moreover, the idea of writing something with Bengali Unicode was new. … in the beginning, the idea of a Wikipedia in Bengali was not actually workable.”<ref name="auto1"/>}}
Between 2009 and 2010, Bengali speakers from [[West Bengal]], India also started to contribute to Bengali Wikipedia.<ref name="auto1"/> In the meantime, the [[Wikimedia Foundation]] started their operations and in October 3, 2011 a local chapter named [[Wikimedia Bangladesh]] was approved in Bangladesh<ref name="auto"/> by the Foundation to promote educational content in Bengali. On February 26, 2015, [[Jimmy Wales]], the co-founder of Wikipedia—visited Bangladesh for a celebration program that was organized by [[Wikimedia Bangladesh]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.prothomalo.com/science-technology/news/59709/Wikipedia-co-founder-arrive-Dhaka|title=Wikipedia co-founder arrive Dhaka|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="prothomalo.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.prothomalo.com/technology/article/463339/%E0%A6%AF%E0%A7%87-%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%BE-%E0%A6%A6%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC%E0%A7%87-%E0%A6%97%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B2%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%A8-%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BF-%E0%A6%93%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%B8|title=যে বার্তা দিয়ে গেলেন জিমি ওয়েলস|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="auto2">{{cite web|url=http://somoynews.tv/pages/details/%E0%A6%A2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC-%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%87%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A1%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0-%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%B9-%E0%A6%AA%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%B0%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%B7%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A0%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%BE-%E0%A6%9C%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%AE%E0%A6%BF-%E0%A6%93%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BC%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%B8|title=ঢাকায় উইকিপিডিয়ার সহ-প্রতিষ্ঠাতা জিমি ওয়েলস|first=|last=webdesk@somoynews.tv|website=somoynews.tv}}</ref> to mark the tenth year of Bengali Wikipedia.<ref name="prothomalo.com"/><ref name="auto2"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://thedhakatimes.com/58671/bengali-wikipedia-third-language/|title=গভীরতার বিচারে বাংলা উইকিপিডিয়ায় তৃতীয় ভাষা - The Dhaka Times|first=The Dhaka|last=Times|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ntvbd.com/tech/2524/%E0%A6%89%E0%A6%87%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A1%E0%A6%BF%E0%A7%9F%E0%A6%BE%E0%A7%9F-%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%83%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%80%E0%A7%9F-%E0%A6%AD%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B7%E0%A6%BE-%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%82%E0%A6%B2%E0%A6%BE|title=উইকিপিডিয়ায় তৃতীয় ভাষা বাংলা|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.prothomalo.com/technology/article/460678/|title=বাংলাদেশে আসছেন জিমি ওয়েলস|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.ntvbd.com/sci-tech/1377/GP-subscribers-get-free-Wikipedia-access/print|title=GP subscribers get free Wikipedia access|first=|last=ntv.com|publisher=}}</ref> In his keynote, Jimmy said that according to the article depth, Bengali Wikipedia is rated quite well.<ref name="prothomalo.com"/>
Bengali Wikipedia now has {{NUMBEROF|ARTICLES|bn|N}} articles on various topics with {{NUMBEROF|ACTIVEUSERS|bn|N}} active editors per month. As of September 2018, Bengali Wikipedia is the only online free encyclopedia written in Bengali language.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kalerkantho.com/feature/chakriache/2015/02/18/189075|title=জেনে রাখুন - কালের কণ্ঠ|first=Kaler|last=Kantho|publisher=}}</ref> It is also one of the largest Bengali content related sites on the internet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kalerkantho.com/print-edition/world/2010/02/19/33256|title=- কালের কণ্ঠ|first=Kaler|last=Kantho|publisher=}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Bhamidipati Ramagopalam(Bharago) | caption = Bhamidipati Ramagopalam(Bharago) | birth_date = {{Birth date |df=yes|1932|2|6}} | death_date = {{Death date |df=yes|2010|4|7}} | birth_place = Pushpagiri, [[Vizianagaram]], [[Andhra Pradesh]], [[India]] | death_place = [[Visakhapatnam]], [[Andhra Pradesh]], [[India]] | occupation = Humor writer of stories in [[Telugu language|Telugu]] }} '''Bhamidipati Ramagopalam''' (1932–2010),<ref name="remembering-bharago">[http://www.thehindu.com/books/remembering-bharago/article397065.ece Remembering Bharago - The Hindu<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.hindu.com/2010/04/15/stories/2010041560010300.htm The Hindu : Andhra Pradesh / Visakhapatnam News : Rich tributes paid to Bharago<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> popularly known as '''Bharago''' is a humour writer of short stories, critiques and popular novels in [[Telugu people|Telugu]], received [[Sahitya Akademi Award|Central Sahitya Academy Award]] in 1991 for the book ''Itlu mee vidheyudu''.<ref>[http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/07/21/stories/2003072101240400.htm The Hindu : He writes for self-edification<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== Education == Ramagopalam had regular schooling from III form onwards at M.R. Branch College and later he graduated in B.A. Economics in 1951 from M.R. Degree College, Vizianagaram.<ref name="remembering-bharago" />
== Adaptations == His short stories have been adapted into mini-series in Telugu by Doordarshan.
== Awards == *Best humour writer award of [[Potti Sreeramulu Telugu University|Telugu University]] (1990) *[[List of Sahitya Akademi Award winners for Telugu|Central Sahitya Academy Award]] (1991) *Kurella Sahithi Award (1994) *Kalasagara (Chennai) Award (1997)
== Works ==
=== Novels === *Kundapenkulu (1961) *Sparsa Rekha (1984) *Nakee Udyogam Vaddu (1988)
=== Stories === *Vantochina Mogudu (1966) *Vennela Needa (1997) *Kadhanakutoohalam (1985) *Itlu Mee Vidheyudu (1990) *Sarada and Kulasa Kadhalu (1997)
=== Others === *Kalpasootram from Prakrit into Telugu *116 Telugu film songs of the period 1942-73 under the name 'Noota padaharlu(2001)'<ref>[http://www.hindu.com/fr/2005/07/22/stories/2005072201260200.htm The Hindu : Entertainment Hyderabad / Books : Bharago's latest<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *Telugu film songs under the name 'Maro Noota padaharlu'(2005)<ref>[http://www.hindu.com/2005/09/30/stories/2005093008170200.htm The Hindu : Andhra Pradesh / Visakhapatnam News : *Bharago's book release on 1 October<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *Anusthana Bhagavadgeetha (2001) *Several commemoration volumes (souvenir) which included the ones on great personalities like [[Dwaram Venkataswamy Naidu]], [[Bhanumathi Ramakrishna|P. Bhanumathi]], [[Raavu Balasaraswathi|Ravu Balasaraswathi]], [[Palagummi Padmaraju]], and [[Rachakonda Viswanatha Sastry|Raavi Sastry]].<ref>[http://www.hindu.com/2010/04/08/stories/2010040860830400.htm The Hindu : Andhra Pradesh / Visakhapatnam News : Noted writer Bharago dead<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *Souvenir on Suseela<ref>[http://www.hindu.com/fr/2009/09/18/stories/2009091850540200.htm The Hindu : Friday Review Hyderabad / Events : Souvenir on Suseela<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
=== Biography === *‘Aaramagopalam’ - An autobiography of noted short-story and humour<ref>[http://www.hindu.com/2007/08/19/stories/2007081958780300.htm The Hindu : Andhra Pradesh / Visakhapatnam News : *Bharago’s autobiography released<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *Translation of the biography of [[Ashutosh Mukherjee|Asutosh Mukherjee]] from English into Telugu<ref name="remembering-bharago" />

== External links == {{more footnotes|date=August 2013}} *http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/mp/2003/07/21/stories/2003072101240400.htm *http://newindianexpress.com/states/andhra_pradesh/article191891.ece *http://www.koumudi.net/gollapudi/041210_bharago.html *http://www.tana.org/events/tana-and-community-news/2010/04/13/a-tribute-to-bhamidipati-ramagopalam-(bharago)-by-chowdary-v-jampala

{{about-distinguish2|a concept in set and number theory|matrix diagonalization. See [[diagonalization (disambiguation)]] for several other uses of the term in mathematics}}
{{Anchor|Lead}}[[Image:Diagonal argument 01 svg.svg|right|thumb|250px|An illustration of Cantor's diagonal argument (in base 2) for the existence of [[uncountable set]]s. The sequence at the bottom cannot occur anywhere in the enumeration of sequences above.]] [[File:Aplicación 2 inyectiva sobreyectiva02.svg|thumb|An [[infinite set]] may have the same [[cardinality]] as a proper [[subset]] of itself, as the depicted [[bijection]] ''f''(''x'')=2''x'' from the [[natural numbers|natural]] to the [[even numbers|even]] numbers demonstrates. Nevertheless, infinite sets of different cardinalities exist, as '''Cantor's diagonal argument''' shows.]]
In [[set theory]], '''Cantor's diagonal argument''', also called the '''diagonalisation argument''', the '''diagonal slash argument''' or the '''diagonal method''', was published in 1891 by [[Georg Cantor]] as a [[mathematical proof]] that there are [[infinite set]]s which cannot be put into [[bijection|one-to-one correspondence]] with the infinite set of [[natural number]]s.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Georg Cantor |title=Ueber eine elementare Frage der Mannigfaltigkeitslehre |journal=[[Jahresbericht der Deutschen Mathematiker-Vereinigung]] 1890–1891 |volume=1 |pages=75–78 |year=1891|url=https://www.digizeitschriften.de/dms/img/?PID=GDZPPN002113910&physid=phys84#navi}} English translation: {{cite book |last=Ewald |first=William B. (ed.) |title=From Immanuel Kant to David Hilbert: A Source Book in the Foundations of Mathematics, Volume 2 |publisher=Oxford University Press |pages=920–922 |year=1996 |isbn=0-19-850536-1}}</ref><ref name="Simmons1993">{{cite book|author=Keith Simmons| author-link=Keith Simmons (philosopher)| title=Universality and the Liar: An Essay on Truth and the Diagonal Argument|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wEj3Spept0AC&pg=PA20|date=30 July 1993|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-43069-2}}</ref>{{rp|20–}}<ref name="Rubin1976">{{cite book|last1=Rudin|first1=Walter|title=Principles of Mathematical Analysis|date=1976|publisher=McGraw-Hill|location=New York|isbn=0070856133|page=30|edition=3rd}}</ref> Such sets are now known as [[uncountable set]]s, and the size of infinite sets is now treated by the theory of [[cardinal number]]s which Cantor began.
The diagonal argument was not Cantor's [[Cantor's first uncountability proof|first proof]] of the uncountability of the [[real number]]s, which appeared in 1874.<ref>{{Citation |surname=Gray|given=Robert|year=1994 |url=http://www.maa.org/sites/default/files/pdf/upload_library/22/Ford/Gray819-832.pdf |title=Georg Cantor and Transcendental Numbers|journal=[[American Mathematical Monthly]]|volume=101|issue=9|pages=819–832 |doi=10.2307/2975129|jstor=2975129}}</ref><ref name="Bloch2011">{{cite book|last1=Bloch|first1=Ethan D.|title=The Real Numbers and Real Analysis|date=2011|publisher=Springer|location=New York|isbn=978-0-387-72176-7|page=429}}</ref> However, it demonstrates a powerful and general technique that has since been used in a wide range of proofs,<ref>{{cite book |title=The Logic of Infinity |edition=illustrated |first1=Barnaby |last1=Sheppard |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2014 |isbn=978-1-107-05831-6 |page=73 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RXzsAwAAQBAJ}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=RXzsAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA73 Extract of page 73]</ref> including the first of [[Gödel's incompleteness theorems]]<ref name="Simmons1993"/> and Turing's answer to the ''[[Entscheidungsproblem]]''. Diagonalization arguments are often also the source of contradictions like [[Russell's paradox]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/russell-paradox|title=Russell's paradox|publisher=Stanford encyclopedia of philosophy}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Bertrand Russell|title=Principles of mathematics|pages=363–366|publisher=Norton|year=1931}}</ref> and [[Richard's paradox]].<ref name="Simmons1993"/>{{rp|27}}
== Uncountable set == In his 1891 article, Cantor considered the set ''T'' of all infinite [[sequences]] of [[binary digits]] (i.e. each digit is zero or one). He begins with a [[constructive proof]] of the following theorem: :If ''s''<sub>1</sub>, ''s''<sub>2</sub>, … , ''s''<sub>''n''</sub>, … is any enumeration of elements from ''T'', then there is always an element ''s'' of ''T'' which corresponds to no ''s''<sub>''n''</sub> in the enumeration. The proof starts with an enumeration of elements from ''T'', for example: :{| |- | ''s''<sub>1</sub> = || (0, || 0, || 0, || 0, || 0, || 0, || 0, || ...) |- | ''s''<sub>2</sub> = || (1, || 1, || 1, || 1, || 1, || 1, || 1, || ...) |- | ''s''<sub>3</sub> = || (0, || 1, || 0, || 1, || 0, || 1, || 0, || ...) |- | ''s''<sub>4</sub> = || (1, || 0, || 1, || 0, || 1, || 0, || 1, || ...) |- | ''s''<sub>5</sub> = || (1, || 1, || 0, || 1, || 0, || 1, || 1, || ...) |- | ''s''<sub>6</sub> = || (0, || 0, || 1, || 1, || 0, || 1, || 1, || ...) |- | ''s''<sub>7</sub> = || (1, || 0, || 0, || 0, || 1, || 0, || 0, || ...) |- | ... |} Next, a sequence ''s'' is constructed by choosing the 1st digit as [[Ones' complement|complementary]] to the 1st digit of ''s''<sub>''1''</sub> (swapping '''0'''s for '''1'''s and vice versa), the 2nd digit as complementary to the 2nd digit of ''s''<sub>''2''</sub>, the 3rd digit as complementary to the 3rd digit of ''s''<sub>''3''</sub>, and generally for every ''n'', the ''n''<sup>th</sup> digit as complementary to the ''n''<sup>th</sup> digit of ''s''<sub>''n''</sub>. For the example above, this yields: :{| |- | ''s''<sub>1</sub> || = || (<u>'''0'''</u>, || 0, || 0, || 0, || 0, || 0, || 0, || ...) |- | ''s''<sub>2</sub> || = || (1, || <u>'''1'''</u>, || 1, || 1, || 1, || 1, || 1, || ...) |- | ''s''<sub>3</sub> || = || (0, || 1, || <u>'''0'''</u>, || 1, || 0, || 1, || 0, || ...) |- | ''s''<sub>4</sub> || = || (1, || 0, || 1, || <u>'''0'''</u>, || 1, || 0, || 1, || ...) |- | ''s''<sub>5</sub> || = || (1, || 1, || 0, || 1, || <u>'''0'''</u>, || 1, || 1, || ...) |- | ''s''<sub>6</sub> || = || (0, || 0, || 1, || 1, || 0, || <u>'''1'''</u>, || 1, || ...) |- | ''s''<sub>7</sub> || = || (1, || 0, || 0, || 0, || 1, || 0, || <u>'''0'''</u>, || ...) |- | ... |- | |- | ''s'' || = || (<u>'''1'''</u>, || <u>'''0'''</u>, || <u>'''1'''</u>, || <u>'''1'''</u>, || <u>'''1'''</u>, || <u>'''0'''</u>, || <u>'''1'''</u>, || ...) |} By construction, ''s'' differs from each ''s''<sub>''n''</sub>, since their ''n''<sup>th</sup> digits differ (highlighted in the example). Hence, ''s'' cannot occur in the enumeration.
Based on this theorem, Cantor then uses a [[proof by contradiction]] to show that: :The set ''T'' is uncountable. The proof starts by assuming that ''T'' is [[countable set#Definition|countable]]. Then all its elements can be written as an enumeration ''s''<sub>1</sub>, ''s''<sub>2</sub>, … , ''s''<sub>''n''</sub>, … . Applying the previous theorem to this enumeration produces a sequence ''s'' not belonging to the enumeration. However, this contradicts ''s'' being an element of ''T'' and therefore belonging to the enumeration. This contradiction implies that the original assumption is false. Therefore, ''T'' is uncountable.
=== Interpretation === The interpretation of Cantor's result will depend upon one's view of mathematics. To [[constructivism (mathematics)|constructivists]], the argument shows no more than that there is no [[bijection]] between the natural numbers and ''T''. It does not rule out the possibility that the latter are [[subcountable]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} In the context of [[classical mathematics]], this is impossible, and the diagonal argument establishes that, although both sets are infinite, there are actually ''more'' infinite sequences of ones and zeros than there are natural numbers.{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}}
=== Real numbers === The uncountability of the [[real number]]s was already established by [[Cantor's first uncountability proof]], but it also follows from the above result. To prove this, an [[injective function|injection]] will be constructed from the set ''T'' of infinite binary strings to the set '''R''' of real numbers. Since ''T'' is uncountable, the [[Image (mathematics)|image]] of this function, which is a subset of '''R''', is uncountable. Therefore, '''R''' is uncountable. Also, by using a method of construction devised by Cantor, a [[bijection]] will be constructed between ''T'' and '''R'''. Therefore, ''T'' and '''R''' have the same cardinality, which is called the "[[cardinality of the continuum]]" and is usually denoted by <math>\mathfrak{c}</math> or <math>2^{\aleph_0}</math>.
An injection from ''T'' to '''R''' is given by mapping strings in ''T'' to decimals, such as mapping ''t'' = 0111… to the decimal 0.0111…. This function, defined by {{nowrap|''f''{{space|hair}}(''t'') {{=}} 0.''t''}}, is an injection because it maps different strings to different numbers.
Instead of mapping 0111… to the decimal 0.0111…, it can be mapped to the [[radix|base]] ''b'' number: 0.0111…<sub>''b''</sub>. This leads to the family of functions: {{nowrap|''f''<sub>''b''</sub>{{space|hair}}(''t'') {{=}} 0.''t''<sub>''b''</sub>}}. The functions {{nowrap|''f''{{space|hair}}<sub>''b''</sub>(''t'')}} are injections, except for {{nowrap|''f''{{space|hair}}<sub>2</sub>(''t'')}}. This function will be modified to produce a bijection between ''T'' and '''R'''.
{| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" |- ! Construction of a bijection between ''T'' and '''R''' |- style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top" | {{multiple image|total_width=200|image1=Linear transformation svg.svg|width1=106|height1=159|caption1=The function ''h'': (0,1) → (−π/2,π/2)|image2=Tangent one period.svg|width2=338|height2=580|caption2=The function tan: (−π/2,π/2) → '''R'''}} This construction uses a method devised by Cantor that was published in 1878. He used it to construct a bijection between the [[closed interval]] [0, 1] and the [[irrational number|irrational]]s in the [[open interval]] (0, 1). He first removed a [[countably infinite]] subset from each of these sets so that there is a bijection between the remaining uncountable sets. Since there is a bijection between the countably infinite subsets that have been removed, combining the two bijections produces a bijection between the original sets.<ref>See page 254 of {{Citation|author=Georg Cantor|title=Ein Beitrag zur Mannigfaltigkeitslehre|url=http://www.digizeitschriften.de/dms/img/?PID=GDZPPN002156806|volume=84|pages=242–258|journal=Journal für die Reine und Angewandte Mathematik|year=1878}}. This proof is discussed in {{Citation|author=Joseph Dauben|title=Georg Cantor: His Mathematics and Philosophy of the Infinite|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=1979|isbn=0-674-34871-0}}, pp. 61–62, 65. On page 65, Dauben proves a result that is stronger than Cantor's. He lets "''φ<sub>ν</sub>'' denote any sequence of rationals in [0, 1]." Cantor lets ''φ<sub>ν</sub>'' denote a sequence [[Enumeration|enumerating]] the rationals in [0, 1], which is the kind of sequence needed for his construction of a bijection between [0, 1] and the irrationals in (0, 1).</ref>
Cantor's method can be used to modify the function {{nowrap|''f''{{space|hair}}<sub>2</sub>(''t'') {{=}} 0.''t''<sub>2</sub>}} to produce a bijection from ''T'' to (0, 1). Because some numbers have two binary expansions, {{nowrap|''f''{{space|hair}}<sub>2</sub>(''t'')}} is not even [[injective function|injective]]. For example, {{nowrap|''f''{{space|hair}}<sub>2</sub>(1000…) {{=}}}} 0.1000…<sub>2</sub> = 1/2 and {{nowrap|''f''{{space|hair}}<sub>2</sub>(0111…) {{=}}}} 0.0111…<sub>2</sub> = {{nowrap|[[Infinite series|1/4 + 1/8 + 1/16 + …]] {{=}}}} 1/2, so both 1000… and 0111… map to the same number, 1/2.
To modify {{nowrap|''f''<sub>2</sub>{{space|hair}}(''t'')}}, observe that it is a bijection except for a countably infinite subset of (0, 1) and a countably infinite subset of ''T''. It is not a bijection for the numbers in (0, 1) that have two [[binary expansion]]s. These are called [[dyadic_rational|dyadic]] numbers and have the form {{nowrap|''m''{{space|hair}}/{{space|hair}}2<sup>''n''</sup>}} where ''m'' is an odd integer and ''n'' is a natural number. Put these numbers in the sequence: ''r'' = (1/2, 1/4, 3/4, 1/8, 3/8, 5/8, 7/8, …). Also, {{nowrap|''f''<sub>2</sub>{{space|hair}}(''t'')}} is not a bijection to (0, 1) for the strings in ''T'' appearing after the [[binary point]] in the binary expansions of 0, 1, and the numbers in sequence ''r''. Put these eventually-constant strings in the sequence: ''s'' = ({{color|#808080|000}}…, {{color|#808080|111}}…, 1{{color|#808080|000}}…, 0{{color|#808080|111}}…, 01{{color|#808080|000}}…, 00{{color|#808080|111}}…, 11{{color|#808080|000}}…, 10{{color|#808080|111}}…, ...). Define the bijection ''g''(''t'') from ''T'' to (0, 1): If ''t'' is the ''n''<sup>th</sup> string in sequence ''s'', let ''g''(''t'') be the ''n''<sup>th</sup> number in sequence ''r''{{space|hair}}; otherwise, ''g''(''t'') = 0.''t''<sub>2</sub>.
To construct a bijection from ''T'' to '''R''', start with the [[trigonometric functions|tangent function]] tan(''x''), which is a bijection from (−π/2, π/2) to '''R''' (see the figure shown on the right). Next observe that the [[linear function]] ''h''(''x'') = {{nowrap|π''x'' – π/2}} is a bijection from (0, 1) to (−π/2, π/2) (see the figure shown on the left). The [[function composition|composite function]] tan(''h''(''x'')) = {{nowrap|tan(π''x'' – π/2)}} is a bijection from (0, 1) to '''R'''. Composing this function with ''g''(''t'') produces the function tan(''h''(''g''(''t''))) = {{nowrap|tan(π''g''(''t'') – π/2)}}, which is a bijection from ''T'' to '''R'''. |}
== General sets == [[File:Diagonal argument powerset svg.svg|thumb|250px|Illustration of the generalized diagonal argument: The set ''T'' = {''n''∈ℕ: ''n''∉''f''(''n'')} at the bottom cannot occur anywhere in the range of ''f'':[[natural number|ℕ]]→[[power set|'''''P''''']](ℕ). The example mapping ''f'' happens to correspond to the example enumeration ''s'' in the [[#Lead|above]] picture.]] A generalized form of the diagonal argument was used by Cantor to prove [[Cantor's theorem]]: for every [[Set (mathematics)|set]] ''S'', the [[power set]] of ''S''—that is, the set of all [[subset]]s of ''S'' (here written as '''''P'''''(''S''))—has a larger cardinality than ''S'' itself. This proof proceeds as follows:
Let ''f'' be any [[Function (mathematics)|function]] from ''S'' to '''''P'''''(''S''). It suffices to prove ''f'' cannot be [[surjective]]. That means that some member ''T'' of '''''P'''''(''S''), i.e. some subset of ''S'', is not in the [[Image (mathematics)|image]] of ''f''. As a candidate consider the set:
:''T'' = { ''s'' ∈ ''S'': ''s'' ∉ ''f''(''s'') }.
For every ''s'' in ''S'', either ''s'' is in ''T'' or not. If ''s'' is in ''T'', then by definition of ''T'', ''s'' is not in ''f''(''s''), so ''T'' is not equal to ''f''(''s''). On the other hand, if ''s'' is not in ''T'', then by definition of ''T'', ''s'' is in ''f''(''s''), so again ''T'' is not equal to ''f''(''s''); cf. picture. For a more complete account of this proof, see [[Cantor's theorem]].
===Consequences=== This result implies that the notion of the [[set of all sets]] is an inconsistent notion. If ''S'' were the set of all sets then '''''P'''''(''S'') would at the same time be bigger than ''S'' and a subset of ''S''.
[[Russell's Paradox]] has shown us that [[naive set theory]], based on an [[unrestricted comprehension]] scheme, is contradictory. Note that there is a similarity between the construction of ''T'' and the set in Russell's paradox. Therefore, depending on how we modify the axiom scheme of comprehension in order to avoid Russell's paradox, arguments such as the non-existence of a set of all sets may or may not remain valid.
The diagonal argument shows that the set of real numbers is "bigger" than the set of natural numbers (and therefore, the integers and rationals as well). Therefore, we can ask if there is a set whose [[cardinality]] is "between" that of the integers and that of the reals. This question leads to the famous [[continuum hypothesis]]. Similarly, the question of whether there exists a set whose cardinality is between |''S''| and |'''''P'''''(''S'')| for some infinite ''S'' leads to the [[generalized continuum hypothesis]].
Analogues of the diagonal argument are widely used in mathematics to prove the existence or nonexistence of certain objects. For example, the conventional proof of the unsolvability of the [[halting problem]] is essentially a diagonal argument. Also, diagonalization was originally used to show the existence of arbitrarily hard [[complexity classes]] and played a key role in early attempts to prove [[P versus NP|P does not equal NP]].
===Version for Quine's New Foundations=== The above proof fails for [[W. V. Quine]]'s "[[New Foundations]]" set theory (NF). In NF, the [[unrestricted comprehension|naive axiom scheme of comprehension]] is modified to avoid the paradoxes by introducing a kind of "local" [[type theory]]. In this axiom scheme,
:{ ''s'' ∈ ''S'': ''s'' ∉ ''f''(''s'') }
is ''not'' a set — i.e., does not satisfy the axiom scheme. On the other hand, we might try to create a modified diagonal argument by noticing that
:{ ''s'' ∈ ''S'': ''s'' ∉ ''f''({''s''}) }
''is'' a set in NF. In which case, if '''''P'''''<sub>1</sub>(''S'') is the set of one-element subsets of ''S'' and ''f'' is a proposed bijection from '''''P'''''<sub>1</sub>(''S'') to '''''P'''''(''S''), one is able to use [[proof by contradiction]] to prove that |'''''P'''''<sub>1</sub>(''S'')| < |'''''P'''''(''S'')|.
The proof follows by the fact that if ''f'' were indeed a map ''onto'' '''''P'''''(''S''), then we could find ''r'' in ''S'', such that ''f''({''r''}) coincides with the modified diagonal set, above. We would conclude that if ''r'' is not in ''f''({''r''}), then ''r'' is in ''f''({''r''}) and vice versa.
It is ''not'' possible to put '''''P'''''<sub>1</sub>(''S'') in a one-to-one relation with ''S'', as the two have different types, and so any function so defined would violate the typing rules for the comprehension scheme.

{{Selfref|For assistance with IPA transcriptions of Catalan for Wikipedia articles, see [[Help:IPA/Catalan]].}} {{IPA notice}} {{Catalan language}} The '''[[phonology]] of [[Catalan language|Catalan]]''', a [[Romance language]], has a certain degree of dialectal variation. Although there are two standard dialects, one based on [[Eastern Catalan]] and one based on [[Valencian]], this article deals with features of all or most dialects, as well as regional pronunciation differences. Various studies have focused on different Catalan varieties; for example, {{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|1979}} and {{Harvcoltxt|Mascaró|1976}} analyze Central Eastern varieties, the former focusing on the educated speech of [[Barcelona]] and the latter focusing more on the vernacular of Barcelona, and {{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1986}} does a careful phonetic study of Central Eastern Catalan.{{Harvcoltxt|Hualde|1992|p=367}}For more information on dialectal variety, see {{Harvcoltxt|Veny|1989}}. Catalan is characterized by [[final-obstruent devoicing]], [[lenition]], and [[voicing assimilation]]; a [[vowel system|set]] of 7 or 8 [[phoneme|phonemic]] [[vowel]]s, vowel [[assimilation (phonology)|assimilations]] (including [[vowel harmony]]), many phonetic [[diphthong]]s, and [[vowel reduction]], whose precise details differ between dialects. It also merges with {{IPA|/m/}} (to {{IPAblink|m}}) before {{IPA|/p/}}, {{IPA|/b/}}. * {{note|szr|4}}{{IPA|/s/}}, {{IPA|/z/}}, {{IPA|/r/}} are apical back alveolar {{IPAblink|s̺}}, {{IPAblink|z̺}}, {{IPAblink|r|r̺}},{{cite web|title=Voiceless Alveolar Fricative – Central {{!}} Els Sons del Català|url=http://www.ub.edu/sonscatala/en/sound/voiceless-alveolar-fricative-central}}
{{cite web|title=Voiceless Alveolar Fricative – Nord Occidental {{!}} Els Sons del Català|url=http://www.ub.edu/sonscatala/en/sound/voiceless-alveolar-fricative-nord-occidental}}

{{cite web|title=Voiced Alveolar Affricate – Nord-Occidental {{!}} Els Sons del Català|url=http://www.ub.edu/sonscatala/en/sound/voiced-alveolar-affricate-nord-occidental}}
{{cite web|title=Voiced Alveolar Affricate – Valencià {{!}} Els Sons del Català|url=http://www.ub.edu/sonscatala/en/sound/voiced-alveolar-affricate-valencia}}{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|p=11}} They may be somewhat [[Relative articulation#Advanced and retracted|fronted]], so that the stop component is laminal denti-alveolar, while the fricative component is apical post-dental. * {{note|llny|6}}{{IPA|/ʎ/}}, {{IPA|/ɲ/}} are laminal "front alveolo-palatal" {{IPAblink|ʎ̟}}, {{IPAblink|ɲ̟}}. * {{note|xj|7}} There is some confusion in the literature about the precise phonetic characteristics of {{IPA|/ʃ/}}, {{IPA|/ʒ/}}, {{IPA|/tʃ/}}, and {{IPA|/dʒ/}}; while {{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|Fontdevila|Pallarès|1995|p=288}} and {{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|Espinosa|2007|p=145}} describe them as "back alveolo-palatal", implying that the characters {{IPA|{{angbr|ɕ ʑ tɕ dʑ}}}} would be more accurate, they (and all literature on Catalan) use the characters for [[palato-alveolar consonant|palato-alveolar]] affricates and fricatives while using {{IPA|{{angbr|ɕ ʑ}}}} for alveolo-palatal sounds in examples in other languages like Polish or Chinese.{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1993}}. Here Recasens labels these Catalan sounds as "laminoalveolars palatalitzades"{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|Pallarès|2001}}. Here the authors label these Catalan sounds as "laminal postalveolar"{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|Espinosa|2007|p=145}} Otherwise, sources, like {{Harvcoltxt|Carbonell|Llisterri|1992|p=53}} generally describe them as "postalveolar". === Obstruents === Voiced obstruents undergo [[final-obstruent devoicing]] so that {{lang|ca|fre'''d'''}} ('cold', [[grammatical gender|m.]] [[grammatical number|s.]]) is pronounced with {{IPA|[t]}}, while {{lang|ca|fre'''d'''es}} ('cold', [[grammatical gender|f.]] [[grammatical number|pl.]]) is pronounced with {{IPA|[ð]}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Lloret|2003|p=278}} ==== Stops ==== Voiced stops become [[lenition|lenited]] to approximants in syllable onsets, after continuants: {{IPA|/b/}} → {{IPAblink|β}}, {{IPA|/d/}} → {{IPAblink|ð}}, {{IPA|/ɡ/}} → {{IPAblink|ɣ}}. Exceptions include {{IPA|/d/}} after [[lateral consonant]]s and {{IPA|/b/}} after {{IPA|/f/}}, e.g. {{lang|ca|ull '''d'''e bou}} {{IPA|[ˈuʎ də ˈβɔw]}} ('[[oeil-de-boeuf]]'), {{lang|ca|bolígraf '''b'''oníssim}} {{IPA|[buˈɫiɣɾəv buˈnisim]}} ('excellent ballpoint'). Additionally, {{IPA|/b/}} fails to lenite in non-betacist dialects. In the coda position, these sounds are always realized as stops{{Harvcoltxt|Hualde|1992|p=368}} except in many Valencian dialects, where they are lenited.{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|Espinosa|2005|p=1}} In some Valencian dialects final {{IPA|/p, t, k/}} can be lenited before a vowel: {{lang|ca|to'''t''' açò}} {{IPA|[ˈt̪oð aˈsɔ]}} ('all this').{{Harvcoltxt|Saborit|2009|pp=53}} In some dialects (e.g. many Valencian accents) initial {{IPA|/ɡ/}} can be lenited: {{lang|ca|gata}} {{IPA|[ˈɣat̪a]}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Saborit|2009|pp=57}} In many Catalan dialects (except Valencian), {{IPA|/b/}} and {{IPA|/ɡ/}} may be [[gemination|geminated]] in certain environments (e.g. {{lang|ca|po'''b'''le}} {{IPA|[ˈpɔbːɫə]}} 'village', {{lang|ca|re'''g'''la}} {{IPA|[ˈreɡːɫə]}} 'rule').{{Harvcoltxt|Carbonell|Llisterri|1992|pp=53–55}}{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|pp=190–191}} In [[Balearic dialect|Majorcan]] varieties, {{IPA|/k/}} and {{IPA|/ɡ/}} become {{IPAblink|c}} and {{IPAblink|ɟ}} word-finally and before front vowels, in some of these dialects, this has extended to all environments except before [[liquid consonant|liquids]] and [[back vowel]]s; e.g. {{lang|ca|san'''g'''}} {{IPA|[ˈsaɲc]}} ('blood'). ==== Affricates ==== The phonemic status of affricates is dubious; after other consonants, affricates are in free variation with fricatives, e.g. {{lang|ca|clen'''x'''a}} {{IPA|[ˈkɫɛɲtʃə]}} ~ {{IPA|[ˈkɫɛɲʃə]}} ('hair parting'){{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|pp=11–12}} and may be analyzed as either single phonemes or clusters of a stop and a fricative. * Alveolar affricates, {{IPAblink|ts}} and {{IPAblink|dz}}, occur the least of all affricates.{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|Espinosa|2007|p=144}} ** {{IPA|[dz]}} only occurs intervocalically: {{lang|ca|me'''tz'''ines}} {{IPA|[məˈdzinəs]}} ('toxic substances').{{Harvcoltxt|Hualde|1992|p=370}} ** Instances of {{IPA|[ts]}} arise mostly from compounding; the few lexical instances arise from historical compounding. For instance, {{lang|ca|po'''ts'''er}} {{IPA|[puˈtse]}} ('maybe') comes from {{lang|ca|pot}} ('may') + {{lang|ca|ser}} ('be' [[infinitive|inf]]). As such, {{IPA|[ts]}} does not occur word-initially; other than some rare words of foreign origin (e.g. {{lang|ca|'''ts'''ar}} '[[tsar]]',[http://dlc.iec.cat/results.asp?txtEntrada=tsar Entry for 'tsar'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814193449/http://dlc.iec.cat/results.asp?txtEntrada=tsar |date=2011-08-14 }} in ''Diccionari de llengua catalana'', Second Edition. {{lang|ca|'''ts'''uga}} '[[tsuga]]'[http://dlc.iec.cat/results.asp?txtEntrada=tsuga&operEntrada=0 Entry for 'tsuga'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814193526/http://dlc.iec.cat/results.asp?txtEntrada=tsuga&operEntrada=0 |date=2011-08-14 }} in ''Diccionari de llengua catalana'', Second Edition.), but it may occur word-finally and quite often in cases of heteromorphemic (i.e. across a morpheme boundary) plural endings: {{lang|ca|to'''ts'''}} {{IPA|[ˈtots]}} ('everybody'). * The distribution of [[alveolo-palatal consonant|alveolo-palatal]] affricates, {{IPAblink|tɕ|tʃ}} and {{IPAblink|dʑ|dʒ}}, depends on dialect: ** In Standard Eastern Catalan, word-initial {{IPA|[tʃ]}} is found only in a few words of foreign origin (e.g. {{lang|ca|'''tx'''ec}} '[[Czechs|Czech]]',[http://dlc.iec.cat/results.asp?txtEntrada=txec Entry for 'txec'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814193534/http://dlc.iec.cat/results.asp?txtEntrada=txec |date=2011-08-14 }} in ''Diccionari de llengua catalana'', Second Edition. {{lang|ca|'''Tx'''aikovski}} '[[Tchaikovsky]]') while being found freely intervocalically (e.g. {{lang|ca|fle'''tx'''a}} 'arrow') and word-finally: {{lang|ca|despa'''tx'''}} {{IPA|[dəsˈpatʃ]}} ('office'). ** Standard Eastern Catalan also only allows {{IPA|[dʒ]}} in intervocalic position (e.g. {{lang|ca|me'''tg'''e}} 'medic', {{lang|ca|a'''dj'''unt}} 'enclosed'). Phonemic analyses show word-final occurrences of {{IPA|/dʒ/}} (e.g. {{lang|ca|ra'''ig''' esbiaixat}} {{IPA|[ˈradʒ əzβiəˈʃat]}} 'skew ray'), but final devoicing eliminates this from the surface: {{lang|ca|ra'''ig'''}} {{IPA|[ˈratʃ]}} ('ray'). ** In various other dialects (as well as in emphatic speech),{{Harvcoltxt|Carbonell|Llisterri|1992|p=53}} {{IPA|[tʃ]}} occurs word-initially and after another consonant to the exclusion of {{IPA|[ʃ]}}. These instances of word-initial {{IPA|[tʃ]}} seem to correspond to {{IPA|[ʃ]}} in other dialects, including the standard (on which the orthography is based): {{lang|ca|'''x'''in'''x'''a}} ('bedbug'), pronounced {{IPA|[ˈʃiɲʃə]}} in the standard, is {{IPA|[ˈtʃiɲtʃə]}} in these varieties. ** Similarly, in most of Valencian and southern Catalonia,{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|pp=13–14}} most occurrences of {{IPA|[dʒ]}} correspond to the voiced fricative {{IPA|[ʒ]}} in Standard Eastern Catalan: {{lang|ca|'''g'''el}} {{IPA|[ˈdʒɛɫ]}} ('ice'). There is dialectal variation in regards to affricate length, with long affricates occurring in both Eastern and Western dialects such as in Majorca and few areas in Southern Valencia.{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|Espinosa|2007|pp=148–149}} Also, intervocalic affricates are predominantly long, especially those that are voiced or occurring immediately after a stressed syllable (e.g. {{lang|ca|me'''tg'''e}} {{IPA|[ˈmed.dʒə]}} 'medic').{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|pp=12}} In modern Valencian {{IPA|[dʒ]}} and {{IPA|[ddʒ]}} have merged into {{IPA|/dʒ/}}. ==== Fricatives ==== {{IPA|/v/}} occurs in Balearic, as well as in [[Alguerese]], [[Valencian|standard Valencian]] and some areas in southern Catalonia.{{Harvcoltxt|Veny|2007|p=51}} Everywhere else, it has [[betacism|merged]] with historic {{IPA|/β/}} so that {{IPA|[b]}} and {{IPA|[β]}} occur in complementary distribution.{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|p=13}} In Majorcan, {{IPA|[v]}} and {{IPA|[w]}} are in complementary distribution, with {{IPAblink|v}} occurring before vowels (e.g. {{lang|ca|bla'''v'''a}} {{IPA|[ˈbɫavə]}} 'blue' [[grammatical gender|f.]] vs. {{lang|ca|bla'''u'''}} {{IPA|[ˈbɫaw]}} 'blue' [[grammatical gender|m.]]). In other varieties that have both sounds, they are in contrast before vowels, with neutralization in favor of {{IPAblink|w}} before consonants.{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2002|p=81}} In some Valencian dialects, {{IPA|/s/}} and {{IPA|/ʃ/}} are auditorily similar such that neutralization may occur in the future.{{Harvcoltxt|Rafel|1981}}, cited in {{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|Espinosa|2007|p=147}} That is the case of Northern Valencian where {{IPA|/ʃ/}} is depalatalized{{clarification needed|date=September 2017}} to {{IPA|[js̠ʲ]}} or {{IPA|[js̠]}} as in {{lang|ca|ca'''ix'''a}} ('box'). Central Valencian words like {{lang|ca|m'''ig'''}} ('half') and {{lang|ca|lle'''ig'''}} ('ugly') have been transcribed with {{IPA|[ts]}} rather than the expected {{IPA|[tʃ]}}, and Southern Valencian {{IPA|/tʃ/}} "has been reported to undergo depalatalization without merging with {{IPA|[ts]}}".{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|Espinosa|2007|p=147}} as in {{lang|ca|passe'''ts'''}} ('small steps') versus {{lang|ca|passe'''ig'''}} ('promenade') In [[La Franja|Aragon]] and Central Valencian (the so called {{lang|ca|apitxat}}), voiced fricatives and affricates are missing (i.e. {{IPA|/z/}} has merged with {{IPA|/s/}}, {{IPA|/dʒ/}} has merged with {{IPA|/tʃ/}}, with only voiceless realizations occurring) and {{IPA|/v/}} has merged with the {{IPA|[b ~ β]}} set.{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|p=23}} === Sonorants === While "dark ([[velarization|velarized]]) l", {{IPAblink|ɫ}}, may be a positional allophone of {{IPA|/l/}} in most dialects (such as in the [[syllable coda]]; e.g. {{lang|ca|sò'''l'''}} {{IPA|[ˈsɔɫ]}} 'ground'),{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|Espinosa|2005|p=20}} {{IPA|/l/}} is [[dark l|dark]] irrespective of position in Eastern dialects like Majorcan{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|Espinosa|2005|p=3}} and standard Eastern Catalan (e.g. {{lang|ca|te'''l'''a}} {{IPA|[ˈtɛɫə]}}). The distribution of the two rhotics {{IPA|/r/}} and {{IPA|/ɾ/}} closely parallels [[Spanish phonology#Alternations|that of Spanish]]. Between vowels, the two contrast (e.g. {{lang|ca|mi'''rr'''a}} {{IPA|[ˈmirə]}} 'myrrh' vs. {{lang|ca|mi'''r'''a}} {{IPA|[ˈmiɾə]}} 'look'), but they are otherwise in complementary distribution. {{IPAblink|ɾ}} appears in the onset, except in word-initial position ({{lang|ca|'''r'''uc}}), after {{IPA|/l/}}, {{IPA|/n/}}, and {{IPA|/s/}} ({{lang|ca|hon'''r'''a}}, {{lang|ca|Is'''r'''ael}}), and in [[compound (linguistics)|compounds]], where {{IPAblink|r}} is used. Different dialects vary in regards to rhotics in the coda, with Western Catalan generally featuring {{IPAblink|ɾ}} and Central Catalan dialects like those of Barcelona or Girona featuring a weakly trilled {{IPAblink|r}} unless it precedes a vowel-initial word in the same [[prosodic unit]], in which case {{IPAblink|ɾ}} appears ({{lang|ca|per}} {{IPA|[peɾ]}} in Western Catalan, {{IPA|[per]}} in Central Catalan).{{Harvcoltxt|Padgett|2003|p=2}} There is free variation in "r" word-initially, after {{IPA|/l/}}, {{IPA|/n/}}, and {{IPA|/s/}}, and in compounds (if {{IPA|/r/}} is preceded by consonant), wherein {{IPA|/r/}} is pronounced {{IPA|[r]}} or [{{IPAlink|ɹ}}], the latter being similar to English '''''r'''ed'': {{IPA|[r ~ ɹ]}}{{lang|ca|uc}}, {{lang|ca|hon}}{{IPA|[r ~ ɹ]}}{{lang|ca|a}}, {{lang|ca|Is}}{{IPA|[r ~ ɹ]}}{{lang|ca|ael}}. In careful speech, {{IPA|/n/}}, {{IPA|/m/}}, and {{IPA|/l/}} may be [[gemination|geminated]] (e.g. {{lang|ca|i'''nn'''ecessari}} {{IPA|[inːəsəˈsaɾi]}} 'unnecessary'; {{lang|ca|e'''mm'''agatzemar}} {{IPA|[əmːəɣədzəˈma]}} 'to store'; {{lang|ca|i'''l·l'''usió}} {{IPA|[iɫːuziˈo]}} 'illusion'). A geminated {{IPA|/ʎʎ/}} may also occur (e.g. {{lang|ca|ra'''tll'''a}} {{IPA|[ˈraʎːə]}} 'line'). {{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|1979}} analyzes intervocalic {{IPA|[r]}} as the result of gemination of a single rhotic phoneme: {{lang|ca|se'''rr'''a}} {{IPA|/ˈsɛɾɾə/ → [ˈsɛrə]}} 'saw, mountains' (this is similar to the common analysis of Spanish and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] rhotics).See {{Harvcoltxt|Bonet|Mascaró|1997}} for more information {{See also|Catalan_phonology#Assimilations|l1=Assimilations}} == Vowels == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ Vowels of Catalan ! ! [[Open vowel|Open]] | colspan="3" | {{IPA link|a}} |} Phonetic notes: * The vowel {{IPA|/a/}} is further back and open than the Castilian counterpart in North-Western and Central Catalan, slightly fronted and closed in Valencian and Ribagorçan {{IPA|[{{IPA link|ä}} ~ {{IPA link|ɐ}}]}}, and further fronted and closed {{IPA|[{{IPA link|a}} ~ {{IPA link|æ}}]}} in Majorcan.{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|pp=90–92}} * The mid-open vowels {{IPA|/ɛ/}} and {{IPA|/ɔ/}} are lower in Majorcan, Minorcan and Valencian, that is, in these dialects the phonetic realization of {{IPA|/ɛ/}} approaches {{IPAblink|æ}}, while {{IPA|/ɔ/}} is as low as {{IPAblink|ɒ}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|pp=81}}{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|pp=130–131}} * In [[Alguerese]], [[Northern Catalan]] and some places bordering the [[Spanish language|Spanish-speaking areas]], mid-open and close-mid vowels may merge into mid vowels; {{IPAblink|e̞}} and {{IPAblink|o̞}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|p=59}} * The high vowels {{IPA|/i, u/}} are more open than in Castilian. Unstressed {{IPA|/i, u/}} are centralized.{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1991|p=66}} ** In Valencian and most Balearic dialects {{IPA|/i, u/}} are further open and centralized * Northern Catalan sometimes adds two loan [[rounded vowel]]s, {{IPAblink|y}} and {{IPAblink|ø̞}}, from [[French language|French]] and [[Occitan language|Occitan]] (e.g. {{lang|ca|b'''u'''t}} {{IPA|[ˈbyt]}} 'aim', {{lang|ca|f'''u'''lles}} {{IPA|[ˈfø̞jəs]}} 'leaves').{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|pp=69, 80–81}} * In the [[Barcelona metropolitan area]] unstressed [[mid-central vowel|schwa]] is lowered to a near-open central vowel {{IPAblink|ɐ}}, sounding closer to {{lang|ca|b'''u'''t}} in [[Received Pronunciation|RP]] or [[Californian English]].{{Harvcoltxt|Harrison|1997|pp=2}} * Phonetic nasalization occurs for vowels occurring between nasal consonants or when preceding a syllable-final nasal; e.g. {{lang|ca|dium'''e'''nge}} {{IPA|[diwˈmẽɲʒə]}} ('Sunday').{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|p=70}} === Stressed vowels === [[File:Catalan vowel chart.svg|The vowel phonemes of Standard Eastern Catalan|thumb|upright=1.13|[[Vowel]]s of Standard Eastern Catalan, from {{Harvcoltxt|Carbonell|Llisterri|1999|p=62}}]] [[File:Valencian vowel chart.svg|The vowel phonemes of Valencian|thumb|upright=1.13|Vowels of Valencian, from {{Harvcoltxt|Saborit Vilar|2009|p=23}}]] Most varieties of Catalan contrast seven stressed vowel phonemes.{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|p=38}} However, some Balearic dialects have an additional stressed vowel phoneme ({{IPAslink|ə}}); e.g. {{lang|ca|s'''e'''c}} {{IPA|/ˈsək/}} ('dry'). The stressed [[mid-central vowel|schwa]] of these dialects corresponds to {{IPA|/ɛ/}} in Central Catalan and {{IPA|/e/}} in Western Catalan varieties (that is, [[Central Catalan|Central]] and [[Western Catalan]] dialects differ in their incidence of {{IPA|/e/}} and {{IPA|/ɛ/}}, with {{IPA|/e/}} appearing more frequently in Western Catalan; e.g. [[Central Catalan]] {{lang|ca|s'''e'''c}} {{IPA|/ˈsɛk/}} vs. [[Western Catalan]] {{lang|ca|s'''e'''c}} {{IPA|/ˈsek/}} 'dry, I sit'). However there are some dialectal differences: [[Alguerese]] merges {{IPA|/a/}}, {{IPA|/e/}}, and {{IPA|/ɛ/}} with {{IPA|[a]}}; and in most areas of Majorca, {{IPA|[o]}} can appear in unstressed position (that is, {{IPA|/o/}} and {{IPA|/ɔ/}} are usually reduced to {{IPA|[o]}}).{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|p=54}} In [[Western Catalan]], vowels in unstressed position reduce to five: {{IPA|/e/}}, {{IPA|/ɛ/ → [e]}}; {{IPA|/o/}}, {{IPA|/ɔ/ → [o]}}; {{IPA|/a/, /u/, /i/}} remain unchanged.{{Harvcoltxt|Carbonell|Llisterri|1992|pp=54–55}} However, in some Western dialects reduced vowels tend to merge into different realizations in some cases: * Unstressed {{IPA|/e/}} may merge with {{IPA|[a]}} before a [[Nasal consonant|nasal]] or [[sibilant consonant]] (e.g. {{lang|ca|'''e'''nclusa}} {{IPA|[aŋˈkluza]}} 'anvil', {{lang|ca|'''e'''ixam}} {{IPA|[ajˈʃam]}} 'swarm'), in some environments before any [[consonant]] (e.g. {{lang|ca|t'''e'''rròs}} {{IPA|[taˈrɔs]}} 'earthy'), and in monosyllabic [[clitic]]s.{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|pp=75–76}} Likewise, unstressed {{IPA|/e/}} may merge into {{IPA|[i]}} when in contact with [[alveolo-palatal consonant|palatal consonants]] (e.g. {{lang|ca|s'''e'''nyor}} {{IPA|[siˈɲo(ɾ)]}} 'lord').{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|pp=128–129}} * Unstressed {{IPA|/o/}} may merge with {{IPA|[u]}} before a [[bilabial consonant]] (e.g. {{lang|ca|c'''o'''bert}} {{IPA|[kuˈβɛɾt]}} 'covered'), before a stressed syllable with a [[high vowel]] (e.g. {{lang|ca|c'''o'''nill}} {{IPA|[kuˈniʎ]}} 'rabbit'), in contact with [[alveolo-palatal consonants|palatal consonants]] (e.g. {{lang|ca|J'''o'''sep}} {{IPA|[(d)ʒuˈzɛp]}} 'Joseph'), and in monosyllabic clitics.{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|pp=138}} {{div col}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+Eastern Catalan |- ! [[Help:IPA|IPA]] ! word ! gloss ! [[Help:IPA|IPA]] ! word ! gloss |- | {{IPA|[jəw]}} || {{lang|ca|dú'''ieu'''}} || 'you carried' || || || |- | {{IPA|[jɛw]}} || {{lang|ca|cre'''ieu'''}} || 'you believe' || {{IPA|[wɛw]}} || {{lang|ca|liq'''üeu'''}} || 'you blend' |- | || || || {{IPA|[waj]}} || {{lang|ca|g'''uai'''ta}} || 'he watches' |- | || || || {{IPA|[wəj]}} || {{lang|ca|g'''uai'''tar}} || 'to watch' |} In standard Eastern Catalan, rising diphthongs (that is, those starting with {{IPA|[j]}} or {{IPA|[w]}}) are only possible in the following contexts:[http://www2.iec.cat/institucio/seccions/Filologica/gramatica/fonetica/05diftongstriftongshiats.pdf Institut d'Estudis Catalans] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100930153153/http://www2.iec.cat/institucio/seccions/Filologica/gramatica/fonetica/05diftongstriftongshiats.pdf |date=2010-09-30 }} ''Els diftongs, els triftongs i els hiats – Gramàtica de la Llengua Catalana'' (provisional draft) * {{IPA|[j]}} in word-initial position, e.g. {{lang|ca|'''i'''ogurt}}. * Both occur between vowels as in {{lang|ca|fe'''i'''a}} and {{lang|ca|ve'''i'''em}}.{{clarify|reason=Can {{IPA|/j/}} and {{IPA|/w/}} be adjacent, as in something like -auia- or -aiua-?|date=May 2015}} * In the sequences {{IPA|[ɡw]}} or {{IPA|[kw]}} and vowel, e.g. {{lang|ca|g'''u'''ant}}, {{lang|ca|q'''u'''ota}}, {{lang|ca|q'''ü'''estió}}, {{lang|ca|ping'''ü'''í}} (these exceptional cases even lead some scholarse.g. {{Harvcoltxt|Lleó|1970}}, {{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|1979}} to hypothesize the existence of rare labiovelar phonemes {{IPA|/ɡʷ/}} and {{IPA|/kʷ/}}).{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|p=101}} == Processes == There are certain instances of ''compensatory diphthongization'' in Majorcan so that {{lang|ca|troncs}} {{IPA|/ˈtɾoncs/}} ('logs') (in addition to deleting the palatal stop) develops a compensating palatal glide and surfaces as {{IPA|[ˈtɾojns]}} (and contrasts with the unpluralized {{IPA|[ˈtɾoɲc]}}). Diphthongization compensates for the loss of the palatal stop (segment loss compensation). There are other cases where diphthongization compensates for the loss of point of articulation features (property loss compensation) as in {{IPA|[ˈaɲ]}} ('year') vs. {{IPA|[ˈajns]}} ('years').{{Harvcoltxt|Mascaró|2002|pp=580–581}} The dialectal distribution of compensatory diphthongization is almost entirely dependent on the dorsal stop ({{IPA|/k~c/}}) and the extent of consonant assimilation (whether or not it is extended to palatals).{{Harvcoltxt|Mascaró|2002|pp=581}} Voiced affricates are devoiced after stressed vowels in dialects like Eastern Catalan where there may be a correlation between devoicing and lengthening ([[gemination]]) of voiced affricates: {{lang|ca|me'''tg'''e}} {{IPA|/ˈmeddʒə/}} → {{IPA|[ˈmettʃə]}} ('medic'). In Barcelona, voiced stops may be [[fortition|fortified]] (geminated and devoiced); e.g. {{lang|ca|poble}} {{IPA|[ˈpɔpːɫə]}} 'village'). === Assimilations === {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! colspan="3" | [[nasal stop|Nasal]] ! colspan="3" | [[lateral consonant|Lateral]] |- ! word ! [[Help:IPA|IPA]] ! gloss ! word ! [[Help:IPA|IPA]] ! gloss |- | í'''n'''fim || {{IPA|[ˈiɱfim]}} || 'lowest' || style="background:#fff solid 1px" colspan="3" | |- | a'''n'''terior || {{IPA|[ən̪təɾiˈo]}} || 'previous' || a'''l'''tes || {{IPA|[ˈaɫ̪təs]}} || 'tall' ([[grammatical gender|f.]] [[plural|pl.]]) |- | e'''n'''gegar || {{IPA|[əɲʒəˈɣa]}} || 'to start (up)' || à'''l'''gid || {{IPA|[ˈaʎʒit]}} || 'decisive' |- | sa'''n'''g || {{IPA|[saŋ(k)]}} || 'blood' || style="background:#fff solid 1px" colspan="3" | |- | sa'''gn'''a || {{IPA|[ˈsaŋnə]~[ˈsaɡnə]}} || 'he bleeds' || style="background:#fff solid 1px" colspan="3" | |- | co'''tn'''a || {{IPA|[ˈkonːə]}} || 'rind' || a'''tl'''es || {{IPA|[ˈaɫːəs]~[ˈadɫəs]}} || 'atlas' |- | | so'''tm'''etent || {{IPA|[sumːəˈten]}} || 'submitting' || mo'''tll'''e || {{IPA|[ˈmɔʎːə]}} || 'spring, mold' |} Catalan denti-alveolar stops can fully [[assimilation (linguistics)|assimilate]] to the following consonant, producing [[gemination]]; this is particularly evident before [[Nasal consonant|nasal]] and [[lateral consonant]]s: e.g. {{lang|ca|co'''tn'''a}} ('rind'), {{lang|ca|mo'''tll'''e}}/{{lang|ca|mo'''tl'''e}} ('spring'), and {{lang|ca|se'''tm'''ana}} ('week'). Learned words can alternate between featuring and not featuring such assimilation (e.g. {{lang|ca|atles}} {{IPA|[ˈadɫəs]~[ˈaɫːəs]}} 'atlas', {{lang|ca|administrar}} {{IPA|[ədminisˈtɾa]~[əmːinisˈtɾa]}} 'to administer').{{Harvcoltxt|Fabra|2008|p=24}}{{Harvcoltxt|Lacreu|2002|p=53}} Central Valencian features simple elision in many of these cases (e.g {{lang|ca|co'''tn'''a}} {{IPA|[ˈkona]}}, {{lang|ca|se'''tm'''ana}} {{IPA|[seˈmana]}}) though learned words don't exhibit either assimilation or elision: {{lang|ca|atles}} {{IPA|[ˈadles]}} and {{lang|ca|administrar}} {{IPA|[adminisˈtɾaɾ]}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|pp=36}} == Prosody == === Stress === Stress most often occurs on any of the last three syllables of a word (e.g. {{lang|ca|brúixola}} {{IPA|[ˈbɾuʃuɫə]}} 'compass', {{lang|ca|càstig}} {{IPA|[ˈkastik]}} 'punishment', {{lang|ca|pallús}} {{IPA|[pəˈʎus]}} 'fool'). Compound words and adverbs formed with {{IPA|/ˈment/}} may have more than one stressed syllable (e.g. {{lang|ca|bonament}} {{IPA|[ˈbɔnəˈmen]}} 'willingly'; {{lang|ca|parallamps}} {{IPA|[ˈpaɾəˈʎams]}} 'lightning conductor') but every lexical word has just one stressed syllable.{{Harvcoltxt|Carbonell|Llisterri|1999|p=63}} === Phonotactics === Any consonant, as well as {{IPA|[j]}} and {{IPA|[w]}} may be an onset. Clusters may consist of a consonant plus a semivowel (C{{IPA|[j]}}, C{{IPA|[w]}}) or an obstruent plus a [[liquid consonant|liquid]]. Some speakers may have one of these obstruent-plus-liquid clusters preceding a semivowel, e.g. {{lang|ca|síndria}} {{IPA|[ˈsin.dɾjə]}} ('watermelon'); for other speakers, this is pronounced {{IPA|[ˈsin.dɾi.ə]}} (i.e. the semivowel must be syllabic in this context).{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|p=78}} Word-medial codas are restricted to one consonant + {{IPA|[s]}} ({{lang|ca|extra}} {{IPA|[ˈɛks.tɾə]}}).{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|p=166}} In the coda position, voice contrasts among obstruents are neutralized.{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|p=145}} Although there are exceptions (such as {{lang|ca|futur}} {{IPA|[fuˈtur]}} 'future'), syllable-final [[rhotic consonant|rhotics]] are often lost before a word boundary or before the plural morpheme of most words: {{lang|ca|colo'''r'''}} {{IPA|[kuˈɫo]}} ('color') vs. {{lang|ca|colo'''r'''aina}} {{IPA|[kuɫuˈɾajnə]}} ('bright color'). In Central Eastern Catalan, obstruents fail to surface word-finally when preceded by a [[homorganic]] consonant (e.g. {{IPA|/nt/ → [n]}}). Complex codas simplify only if the loss of the segment doesn't result in the loss of place specification.{{Harvcoltxt|Herrick|2002|p=70}} {| class="wikitable" |+Suffixation examples |- ! ! colspan="2" | Final ! gloss ! colspan="2" | Internal ! gloss |- ! rowspan="6" | no cluster | cam'''p''' || {{IPA|[ˈkam]}} || 'field' || cam'''p'''erol || {{IPA|[kəmpəˈɾɔɫ]}} || 'peasant' |- | pun'''t''' || {{IPA|[ˈpun]}} || 'point' || pun'''t'''a || {{IPA|[ˈpuntə]}} || 'tip' |- | ban'''c''' || {{IPA|[ˈbaŋ]}} || 'bank' || ban'''c'''a || {{IPA|[ˈbaŋkə]}} || 'banking' |- | malal'''t''' || {{IPA|[məˈɫaɫ]}} || 'ill' || malal'''t'''ia || {{IPA|[məɫəɫˈti.ə]}} || 'illness' |- | hor'''t''' || {{IPA|[ˈɔr]}} || 'orchard' || hor'''t'''alissa || {{IPA|[urtəˈɫisə]}} || 'vegetable' |- | gus'''t''' || {{IPA|[ˈɡus]}} || 'taste' || gus'''t'''ar || {{IPA|[ɡusˈta]}} || 'to taste' |- ! rowspan="3" | cluster | ser'''p''' || {{IPA|[ˈserp]}} || 'snake' || ser'''p'''entí || {{IPA|[sərpənˈti]}} || 'snake-like' |- | dis'''c''' || {{IPA|[ˈdisk]}} || 'disk' || |dis'''qu'''et || {{IPA|[disˈkɛt]}} || 'diskette' |- | remol'''c''' || {{IPA|[rəˈmɔɫk]}} || 'trailer' || remol'''c'''ar || {{IPA|[rəmuɫˈka]}} || 'to tow' |} When the suffix {{lang|ca|-erol}} {{IPA|[əˈɾɔɫ]}} is added to {{lang|ca|camp}} {{IPA|[ˈkam]}} it makes {{IPA|[kəmpəˈɾɔɫ]}}, indicating that the underlying representation is |{{IPA|ˈkamp}}| (with subsequent cluster simplification), however when the copula {{IPA|[ˈes]}} is added it makes {{IPA|[ˈkam ˈes]}}. The resulting generalization is that this underlying {{IPA|/p/}} will only surface in a morphologically complex word.{{Harvcoltxt|Herrick|2002|p=72}} Despite this, word-final codas are not usually simplified in most of Balearic and Valencian (e.g. {{lang|ca|cam'''p'''}} {{IPA|[ˈkamp]}}).{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|p=192}} Word-initial clusters from Graeco-Latin learned words tend to drop the first phoneme: {{lang|ca|'''pn'''eumàtic}} {{IPA|[nəwˈmatik]}} ('pneumatic'), {{lang|ca|'''ps'''eudònim}} {{IPA|[səwˈðɔnim]}} ('pseudonym'), {{lang|ca|'''pt'''erodàctil}} {{IPA|[təɾuˈðaktiɫ]}} ('pterodactylus'), {{lang|ca|'''gn'''om}} {{IPA|[ˈnom]}} ('gnome').{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|p=175}} Word-final obstruents are devoiced, however they assimilate voicing of the following consonant; e.g. {{lang|ca|cu'''c''' de seda}} {{IPA|[ˈkuɡ də ˈsɛðə]}} ('silkworm'). In regular and fast speech, stops often assimilate the place of articulation of the following consonant producing phonetic gemination: {{lang|ca|to'''t''' bé}} {{IPA|[ˈtod ˈbe] → [ˈtob ˈbe]}} ('all good').{{Harvcoltxt|Badia|1988|p=35}} Word-final fricatives (except {{IPA|/f/}}) are voiced before a following vowel; e.g. {{lang|ca|bu'''s''' enorme}} {{IPA|[ˈbuz əˈnormə]}} ('huge bus').{{Citation | author=Recasens, Daniel| year=1991 | title= An Electropalatographic and Acoustic Study of Consonant-to-Vowel Coarticulation | journal=Journal of Phonetics| volume=19 | pages=267–280 | postscript=.}} In Majorcan and Minorcan Catalan, {{IPA|/f/}} undergoes total assimilation to a following consonant (just as stops do): {{lang|ca|bu'''f''' gros}} {{IPA|[ˈbuɡ ˈɡɾɔs]}} ('large puff').{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|pp=81}} == Dialectal variation == [[File:Catalan dialects-en.png|thumb|right|upright=1.36|Dialectal Map of Catalan from {{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|Yates|Dols|1999|p=xviii}}
'''Eastern dialects:''' {{legend|#B67000|[[Northern Catalan]]}} {{legend|#C24851|[[Central Catalan]]}} {{legend|#A55DD3|[[Balearic dialect|Balearic]] and [[Alguerese]]}} '''Western dialects:''' {{legend|#6870FF|[[North-Western Catalan]]}} {{legend|#3AC636|[[Valencian language|Valencian]]}}]] The differences in the vocalic systems outlined above are the main criteria used to differentiate between the major dialects: {{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005}} distinguishes two major dialect groups, [[Western Catalan|western]] and [[Eastern Catalan|eastern dialects]]; the latter of which only allow {{IPAblink|i}}, {{IPAblink|ə}}, and {{IPAblink|u}} to appear in unstressed syllables and include [[Northern Catalan]], [[Central Catalan]], [[Balearic dialect|Balearic]], and [[Alguerese]]. [[Western Catalan|Western dialects]], which allow any vowel in unstressed syllables, include [[Valencian]] and [[North-Western Catalan]]. Regarding consonants, [[betacism]] and fricative–affricate alternations are the most prominent differences between dialects. Other dialectal features are: * [[Vowel harmony]] with {{IPA|/ɔ/}} and {{IPA|/ɛ/}} in Valencian; this process is progressive (i.e. preceding vowels affect those pronounced afterwards) over the last unstressed vowel of a word; e.g. {{lang|ca|h'''o'''ra}} {{IPA|/ˈɔɾa/}} → {{IPA|[ˈɔɾɔ]}}. However, there are cases where [[metaphony|regressive metaphony]] occurs over pretonic vowels; e.g. {{lang|ca|tovall'''o'''la}} {{IPA|/tovaˈʎɔla/}} → {{IPA|[tɔvɔˈʎɔlɔ]}} ('towel'), {{lang|ca|af'''e'''cta}} {{IPA|/aˈfɛkta/}} → {{IPA|[ɛˈfɛktɛ]}} ('affects').{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|p=99}} * In a number of dialects unstressed {{IPA|/i/}} can merge with {{IPA|/ə/}} (Eastern dialects) or {{IPA|/e, a/}} (Western dialects) according to the previous or following vowel (i.e. through assimilation when these vowels are high or dissimilation when they are mid or low). This merger is especially common in words with the prefix {{lang|ca|in}} or {{lang|ca|im}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1991|p=68}} * In Southern Valencian subvarieties, especially in Alicante Valencian, the diphthong {{IPA|/ɔu/}} (phonetically {{IPA|[ɒw]}} in Valencian) has become {{IPA|[ɑw]}}: {{lang|ca|b'''ou'''s}} {{IPA|[ˈbɑws]}} ('bulls').{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|pp=131–132}} * In regular speech in both Eastern and Western Catalan dialects, word-initial unstressed {{IPA|/o/}} –{{IPA|[u]}} or {{IPA|[o]}}– may be diphthongized to {{IPA|[əw]}} (Eastern Catalan) or {{IPA|[aw]}} (Western Catalan): {{lang|ca|'''o'''fegar}} {{IPA|[əwfəˈɣa]~[awfeˈɣa(ɾ)]}} ('to drown, suffocate').{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|pp=138–139}} * In [[La Franja|Aragonese Catalan]] (including [[Ribagorçan]]), {{IPA|/l/}} is palatalized to {{IPAblink|ʎ}} in consonant clusters; e.g. {{lang|ca|p'''l'''ou}} {{IPA|[ˈpʎɔw]}} 'it rains'.{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|pp=311–312}} * In Alguerese and Ribagorçan word-final {{IPA|/ʎ/}} and {{IPA|/ɲ/}} are depalatized to {{IPAblink|l}} and {{IPAblink|n}}, respectively; e.g. {{lang|ca|ga'''ll'''}} {{IPA|[ˈɡal]}} ('rooster'), {{lang|ca|a'''ny'''}} {{IPA|[ˈan]}} ('year').{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1994|p=266}}{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1994|p=321}} * Varying degrees of L-velarization among dialects: {{IPA|/l/}} is [[dark l|dark]] irrespective of position in Balearic and Central Catalan and might tend to [[L-vocalization|vocalization]] in some cases. In Western varieties like Valencian, this dark l contrasts with a [[Clear L|clear l]] in intervocalic and word-initial position; while in other dialects, like Alguerese or Northern Catalan, {{IPA|/l/}} is never velarized in any instance.{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|p=307}} * {{lang|ca|[[:ca:Iodització|Iodització]]}} (also known as {{lang|ca|iesme històric}} "historic {{lang|es|[[yeísmo]]}}") in regular speech in most of Majorcan, Northern Catalan and in the historic comarca of Vallès (Barcelona): {{IPA|/ʎ/}} merges with {{IPA|[j]}} in some Latin-derived words with intervocalic L-palatalization (intervocalic {{IPA|/l/}} + [[Palatal approximant|yod]] (-{{Sc|li}}-, -{{Sc|le}}-), -{{Sc|ll}}-, -{{Sc|cvl}}-, and -{{Sc|gvl}}-); e.g. {{lang|ca|pa'''ll'''a}} {{IPA|[ˈpajə]}} ('straw'). An exception to this rule is initial L-palatalization; e.g. {{lang|ca|'''ll'''una}} {{IPA|[ˈʎunə]}} ('moon').{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|pp=34–35}} * The dorso-palatal {{IPAblink|ʝ}} may occur in complementary distribution with {{IPAblink|ɟ}}, only in Majorcan varieties that have dorso-palatals rather than the velars found in most dialects: {{lang|ca|'''gu'''erra}} {{IPA|[ˈɟɛrə]}} ('war') vs. {{lang|ca|sa '''gu'''erra}} {{IPA|[sə ˈʝɛrə]}} ('the war').{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|pp=22–23}} * In northern and transitional Valencian, word-initial and postconsonantal {{IPA|/dʒ/}} (Eastern Catalan {{IPA|/ʒ/}} and {{IPA|/dʒ ~ ʒ/}}) alternates with {{IPA|[(j)ʒ]}} intervocalically; e.g. {{lang|ca|'''j'''oc}} {{IPA|[ˈdʒɔk]}} 'game', but {{lang|ca|pi'''tj'''or}} {{IPA|[piˈʒo]}} 'worse', {{lang|ca|bo'''j'''a}} {{IPA|[ˈbɔjʒa]}} 'crazy' (standard Valencian {{IPA|/ˈdʒɔk/}}, {{IPA|/piˈdʒoɾ/}}; {{IPA|/ˈbɔdʒa/}}; standard Catalan {{IPA|/ˈʒɔk/}}, {{IPA|/piˈdʒo/}} and {{IPA|/ˈbɔʒə/}}).{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|pp=15}} * In northern Valencia and southern Catalonia {{IPA|/s/}} has merged with realizations of {{IPA|/ʃ/}} after a high front vocoid; e.g. {{lang|ca|terri'''ss'''a}} {{IPA|[teˈriʃa]}} ('pottery'), {{lang|ca|insi'''s'''ti'''s'''c}} {{IPA|[insiʃˈtiʃk]}} ('I insist') vs. {{lang|ca|pi'''x'''ar}} {{IPA|[piˈʃa(ɾ)]}} ('to pee'), {{lang|ca|de'''ix'''ar}} {{IPA|[dejˈʃa(ɾ)]}} ('to leave'). In these varieties {{IPA|/ʃ/}} is not found after other vocoids, and merges with {{IPA|/tʃ/}} after consonants; e.g. {{lang|ca|pun'''x'''a}} {{IPA|[ˈpuɲtʃa]}} ('thorn').{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|p=22}} * Intervocalic {{IPA|/d/}} dropping (particularly [[participle]]s) in regular speech in Valencian, with [[compensatory lengthening]] of vowel {{IPA|/a/}}; e.g. {{lang|ca|vespra'''d'''a}} {{IPA|[vesˈpɾaː]}} ('evening').{{Harvcoltxt|Recasens|1996|pp=91–92}} * In northern Catalonia and in the town of Sóller (Majorca), a uvular trill {{IPAblink|ʀ}} or approximant {{IPAblink|ʁ}} can be heard instead of an alveolar trill; e.g. {{lang|ca|có'''rr'''er}} {{IPA|[ˈkoʀə]~[ˈkoʁə]}} ('to run').{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|p=24}} == Historical development == {{Main|Phonological history of Catalan}} Catalan shares features with neighboring Romance languages ([[Occitan language|Occitan]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Sardinian language|Sardinian]], [[French language|French]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]]).{{Harvcoltxt|Wheeler|2005|p=1}} * Marked contrast of the vowel pairs {{IPA|/ɛ/ ~ /e/}} and {{IPA|/ɔ/ ~ /o/}}, as in other [[Western Romance]] languages, except Spanish and Sardinian.{{sfn|Enciclopèdia Catalana|p = 630}} * Lenition of voiced stops {{IPA|[b]→[β], [d]→[ð], [ɡ]→[ɣ]}} as in Galician and Spanish.{{sfn|Enciclopèdia Catalana|p = 630}} * Lack of [[diphthongization]] of [[Latin]] short {{lang|la|ĕ}}, {{lang|la|ŏ}}, as in [[Galician language|Galician]] and Portuguese, and unlike French, Spanish and Italian.{{sfn|Enciclopèdia Catalana|p = 630}} * Abundance of diphthongs containing {{IPA|/w/}}, as in Galician and Portuguese.{{sfn|Enciclopèdia Catalana|p = 630}} * Abundance of {{IPA|/ʎ/}} and {{IPA|/ɲ/}} occurring at the end of words, as for instance {{wikt-lang|ca|moll}} ("wet") and {{wikt-lang|ca|any}} ("year"), unlike Spanish,{{cite web |url={{Google Books |id=T_DpUtZ66hoC |page=19 |plainurl=yes}} |last=Hall |first=Jacqueline |title=Convivència in Catalonia: Languages Living Together |location=Barcelona |publisher=[[Institut d'Estudis Catalans]] |date=2001 |page=19}} Portuguese or Italian. In contrast with other Romance languages, Catalan has many [[monosyllabic]] words; and those ending in a wide variety of consonants and some [[consonant cluster]]s.{{sfn|Enciclopèdia Catalana|p=630}} Also, Catalan has [[final obstruent devoicing]], thus featuring many couplets like {{lang|ca|amic}} ('male friend') vs. {{lang|ca|amiga}} ('female friend').{{sfn|Enciclopèdia Catalana|p=630}} == See {{EngvarB|date=April 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{disputed|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox writer | name = Chaman Lal Chaman | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth based on age as of date|74|2008|July|30}}<ref name="dna"/> | birth_place = Pasla (now [[Jalandhar district]]), [[British Punjab]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = [[London]], [[England]] | occupation = [[Poet]], [[Lyricist]] | language = [[Punjabi language|Panjabi]], [[Urdu]], [[Hindi language|Hindi]] | nationality = | citizenship = British | education = | alma_mater = | period = | genre = [[Folk music of Punjab|Panjabi]], [[Filmi]] | subject = Social | movement = | notableworks = ''saun da mahina'' (song) | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }}
'''Chaman Lal Chaman''' is a London-based noted [[Punjabi people|Panjabi]] poet, lyricist and radio broadcaster.<ref name="dna">{{cite web | url = http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report_poetry-and-lyrics-are-my-first-love_1180598 | title = 'Poetry and lyrics are my first love' | publisher = DNAIndia.com | date = 30 July 2008 | accessdate = 23 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="bbc">{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b019lxj6 | title=Chaman Lal Chaman talks about his life | publisher=[[BBC]] | accessdate=25 November 2012}}</ref> He is the writer of a popular [[Punjabi language|Panjabi]] song, ''saun da mahina'', sung by [[Jagjit Singh]] in 1979.<ref name="dna"/><ref name="aa">{{cite web | url = http://asianaffairs.in/january2010/press-release.html | title = Chaman blooms in Britain | publisher = AsianAffairs.in | date = January 2010 | accessdate = 23 November 2012 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130217210427/http://asianaffairs.in/january2010/press-release.html | archivedate = 17 February 2013 | df = }}</ref> He also writes in [[Urdu]] and [[Hindi language|Hindi]].
He wrote a [[Bhangra (popular music)|Bhangra]] song for Gurinder Chadha's [[Bride and Prejudice]], starring [[Aishwarya Rai]] with music by [[Anu Malik]], and many songs and ghazals for [[Jagjit Singh]] and his wife [[Chitra Singh]]. His lyrics has also been sung by noted Indian singers like [[Asha Bhosle]], [[Kumar Sanu]] and [[Sonu Nigam]].<ref name="r">{{cite web | url=http://www.glamour.raafatrola.com/songs-and-lyrics/chaman-lal-chaman-song-lyrics | title=Chaman Lal Chaman Song-Lyrics | accessdate=25 November 2012}}</ref>
He worked as a radio presenter in [[Kenya]] and [[Great Britain|Britain]] and interviewed more than a hundred celebrities including, [[Sunil Dutt]], [[Jawahar Lal Nehru]] and [[Naushad]].
He was honored in [[London]] in 2010 and was presented the Asian Achievers Gold Award for his achievements in media, art and culture.<ref name="aa"/><ref name="oa">{{cite web | url=http://www.openarticle.com/article.cfm?id=70E8E412-123D-4467-847611E4ABFED874 | title=CHAMAN BLOOMS IN BRITAIN - Veteran Broadcaster, Poet, Lyricist and Journalist Honoured with a Major Award | publisher=OpenArticle.com | accessdate=25 November 2012 }}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== Early life and works ==
Chaman was born in a small village of [[Jalandhar district|Jalandhar]], Pasla.<ref name="dna"/> His mother died when he was a child and his father called him to [[Kenya]] where he worked as a presenter for Kenyan Radio, The Voice of Kenya, in [[Nairobi]] during the 1950s and 1960s<ref name="dna"/> and interviewed more than a hundred celebrities, including a noted [[Bollywood]] actor [[Sunil Dutt]] when he visited Kenya.
Later, spending nearly 18 years, from 1956 to 1974,<ref name="aa"/> he moved to [[Great Britain|Britain]] and worked at the Asian service of [[BBC]] and Panjab Radio, UK.
He started the first Indian commercial radio programme in London called ''Geetmala'' which became a rage among the Asian diaspora. He also anchored the weekly programmes on BBC's TV One and BBC Radio Four during the 1990s.<ref name="dna"/>
=== Literary works ===
At the age of 13, he wrote a poem on [[Guru Nanak Dev]]'s birthday and was given rupee 1 as an award which stirred his inner poet. After that he wrote many poems and has published three anthologies of his poems.
On the 50th anniversary of India and Pakistan's independence, he penned a play, ''Sare Jahan Se Achha'', directed by the noted Punjabi writer [[Balwant Gargi]] and the music was composed by ghazal singer, [[Jagjit Singh]].<ref name="aa"/> It was a major success when played in [[London]] and other cities of Britain in 1997 and 98.<ref name="oa"/>
